Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response & Recovery

Emergency Preparation

  1. Consult Local Experts

    Consult with local experts such as law enforcement, fire departments, your local health department, and your community Emergency Preparedness Coordinator. Ask for their guidance in establishing community contacts and assistance with writing & reviewing your Emergency Plan.

  2. Review and Establish Communication System

    Review and establish your communication and warning system. It is essential that you can communicate with your staff, local authorities and parents during a disaster. Do not count on cell phones for your only means of communication.

  3. Develop a Written Plan

    Once you have done some preliminary work the next phase of managing emergencies is to develop a written plan.

    LARA has some very helpful templates and sample Emergency/Crisis Management Plans. The Emergency Preparedness Manual from the National Center on Early Childhood Health & Wellness (ECLKC) is also a fantastic resource to aid you in your development of your Emergency Plan Policies and Practices. The guide is full of useful forms the steps to guide you through the process. The links to both resources can be found in the Support Material section at the end of this session.

  4. Practice, Set Up Drills and Revise Plan

    After the plan has been developed, you need to practice it. Set up drills with staff and children. Revise the plan as needed.
